reviewText:
Puzzler world is like a puzzle magazine from a kiosk but you can make 3 different profiles, so also other family members can play the game with an own profile (or you try the puzzles in an other language) and of course you have way more puzzles than the most magazines have.

Variety:
There are different types of puzzles, for example Wordsearch, Sudoku, Fitword, Silhouette, Spot the difference, Crossword, Code word, Hangman and so on. In the challenge mode you can play 560 main puzzles and always when you solved one you are able to play an other mini puzzle. So the amount of puzzles in this mode is 1.120. There is also a Quickplaymode but the puzzles in this mode are so easy that you very probably won‘t play it. Anyways for so many puzzles I give 10/10 points because the most puzzle magazines have like 100-200 puzzles.

Languages & Orthography:
The possible languages which you can choose are: American English, British English, German, Spanish, French and Italian. Of course this is a great selection but maybe they should add also Russian and I can’t give the full points because there are sometimes little spelling mistakes in the game, e. g. I have had a hangman puzzle where I had to search a „panet“ (correct word would be planet) and the result was „merker“ but the planet is called in German „Merkur“ (english = Mercury). Such mistakes are really rare and don’t disturb the game too much so I can give for the languages and ortography 8/10 points.

Graphic:
The graphic is simple. What else? You can’t expect that much from a puzzle game and it’s adequate for some minutes playing puzzles. For the people who want to make all the achievements as fast as they can, I give the adivce to make some breaks between. You don’t have the highest resolution in this game so if you play it for hours you maybe get stinging eyes or a headache. My points: 5/10

Controls:
The controls are really easy. You can use the keyboard or you click on the letters with your mouse. There is also a handwriting recognition function. 10/10

Level of difficulty:
Some of the puzzles are really easy, some are normal. Sometimes you need a bit time to get the solution but it won’t break you if you are into such puzzles. Sadly there is no option to change the level of difficulty. ;(

Achievements:
There are 15 achievements which you get easily. No bugged ones. The only con is that there are no leaderboards.

Price: The normal price for this game is 4,99 €. For so many puzzles this price is okay but I advise to buy the game on a sale. I bought it at Steam Summer Sale for 0,79 € (valuta calculator says: 1,08 Dollar ^^) and for this price I am really happy with this game.
voteText: 47 of 47 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Puzzler World is a huge crossword magazine on your desktop PC: Wordsearch, Fitword, Sudoku, Crossword, Silhouette, Spot the Difference, Code word, Hangman... and many others, in many languages.As far as this game goes it provided me with some light entertainment to kill a few hours here and there and although the resolution could have been tweaked better I refuse to complain considering I bought this game during a sale for 0,79€. There's really nothing negative to say about Puzzler World, it did actually hold my interest and I enjoyed playing. If you enjoy crosswords, Sudoku’s, word searches, letter games and similar puzzles you can’t really go wrong!

reviewText: Puzzler World is not ground breaking, it doesn't look spectacular and the music is a bit annoying but if you are just looking for some classic puzzles then you can't go wrong with this game. What the game gives you that the magazine does not are of useful hints when you need them, but only if you have enough hint tokens that are earned through completing puzzles. You also get way more puzzles than would fit in a magazine and if you pick it up on sale it will cost less than one too.\n\nIf you are expecting an innovative masterpiece that will challenge you then you can give this a pass, if you want something to waste a few minutes now and then to keep your mind engaged then I can recommend this game to you.

reviewText: This game is not perfect, but it is worth having if you enjoy puzzles.\n\nPros: There is a good variety of puzzles (word search, crossword, link-a-pix, codeword, sudoku, spot the difference, fitword, silhouette, and some smaller bonus" games). There is support for multiple languages
date: treating British and American English as two different languages - and they should
recommended: for a game like this. I accidentally tried the British one at first and had a terrible time at the crossword. Then I switched to American and the crossword got MUCH easier. If you're not worried about full completion of the game
hoursPlayed: you can skip as far ahead as you want - all content is open right from the start of the challenge mode. And there is a lot of content - over 1200 puzzles in total.\n\nCons: The difficulty progression is very slow. In the beginning
voteText: the puzzles are tediously easy. Hardcore puzzlers will be a bit annoyed at having to slog through the beginning
helpfulPercent: before the puzzles get hard enough to be really interesting. The proper order of operations is not followed in the "equate" bonus puzzles (they don't do multiplication/division before addition/subtraction like they should)
votesHelpful: but this is easy enough to get used to. The silhouette "puzzles" are really not puzzles at all. Switching languages means you have to start the whole challenge mode over. Puzzles are not randomly generated and once you've solved one
votesTotal: there is no replay value. Too many hint tokens are given
votesFunny: removing some of the challenge from harder puzzles.\n\nThis game is particularly well-suited to younger puzzlers
commentsCount: since the slow increase in difficulty and ease of the starting puzzles make it very comfortable to get started and train your logic brain. However
column17: despite the tedious easy beginning of the game. I've spent a few fun hours on it and I look forward to a quick crossword or link-a-pix each morning to get my brain started."

reviewText:
50 hours of puzzles in Challenge mode which consists of 560 main puzzles and 560 quick bonus puzzles.

The puzzles are VERY EASY all the way through (all 1120 of them).   I prefer my puzzles with the exception of Crosswords to be Hard/Expert level, but I can still enjoy a puzzle if it ranges anywhere from Easy thru to Expert.  Thus I was able to complete all 1120 of them and due to that I give it a thumbs up.

To illustrate just how Easy some of them are:    Hangman -   7 letter Word (English) with the clue Day of the Week".  Pretty hard to miss that one.  If it was an isolated instance I wouldn't comment
date: but the WordFit and the Hangman are beyond easy.  Those two types of puzzle get "epic fail" as they're well beyond easy.  The rest are enjoyable enough.\n\nBuy it on sale.  Recognize that the puzzles are easy
recommended: and so long as you like easy puzzles to chew up a few hours every day you'll enjoy this.  If you can't deal with "Easy" - definitely dont buy this.\n\n"

reviewText:
Puzzler World is a collection of over 1000 puzzles. Some of them are easier, some are harder - but you can acess half of them at any point. Second half are bonus challenges, paired with regular ones. You unlock them by completing first one from the pair.
There are 14 challenges, like crosswords, spot the diffrence, wordsearches, hangman ect. It may seem boring, but completing it is both fun, and challenge.
After each game (both regular and bonus), you pick a present. It may contain a hint, or a letter (7 of them grant you with around 100 hints). Hints are aviable only in regular challenges, and they provide a bit of help when you need it. They are divided into 3 groups: 5, 10 and 20. The more expensive the set is, the bigger is help, and effects vary in diffrent challenges.
Not much more is possible to be said - it looks a bit like childs game at the beggining, but it's actually quite a nice game.
If you like achievements - this is a perfect game. It takes less than 6 hours to get all of them here, as there are only achievements for completing 10 of each challenge, and nothing for having 100% of the game. Only hint - turn off the music as soon as possible.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's a reasonably fun diversion, but there are a few things that make it so that I can't recommend it. First and foremost being that it's not too hard to find puzzles of a similar ilk online for free -- and often with better interfaces. (Just compare the Link-a-Pix in the game to the same found on Conceptis's own website.)  The second problem is that some of the games aren't really puzzles per se... showing the user a picture and asking them to memorize it for three questions isn't a puzzle, it's just a memory test. It's not a puzzle unless one has to puzzle something out. Memorization is just an irritation. There's also a staggering difference in apparent audience between puzzles; the Codeword puzzle is clearly meant for advanced puzzlers, while Silhouette is obviously set for the grade school crowd, but they're all mixed in together.\n\nFinally, though it's a minor element, it bothers me quite a bit that the Equate puzzles" don't follow the proper order of operations. The only thing worse than a puzzle that's stupidly simple is one that's only challenging because the desired answer is actually wrong."

reviewText: When I was young I'd buy booklets filled with crosswords and take them with me on holidays. I enjoyed them a lot and thus Puzzler World is nostalgic for me. Puzzler World will give you around 70 hours of total gameplay (basing on my % of puzzle completion) and it consists of quite a few different puzzle types: 1. Crosswords 2. Codewords 3. Wordsearches 4. Sudoku 5. Fitwords 6. Link-A-Pix 7. Spot the Difference 8. Silhouette  9. Hangman 10. Chainletter 11. Missing Piece 12. Picture Quiz 13.Jigsaw Puzzles and 14. Equate Puzzles. I'm sure you can find these puzzles for free all over the web, but I myself do enjoying having it all easily accessible on Steam. The interface is very outdated and the achievements are underwhelming,  the puzzle types aren't equal in amount of content (very few picture related) and there is no save feature. If you don't mind this and love simple puzzles, grab Puzzler World.

reviewText:
UK’s largest puzzle supplier has someday the idea to concentrate over 1k puzzles into this game.
It contains a dozen different puzzle types like Sudoku, Fillout, Spot the difference and so on.
For every puzzle chosen from a 4x4 matrix you earn coins in a 1 of 3 choice which are payable hintpoints in game. After playing a while the elements are quite repeative with small differences. At puzzle number above 100 the puzzles become a little harder. That means if you started with a 6 number Sudoku now it raises to a 9 number Sudoku (which is formally known as normal Sudoku).
There are 6 languages avaible, unfortunately sometimes with little translation errors in German for example. It's quite fun but sometimes really nerve-wracking.

reviewText:
7 hours to get all Steam achievements, mostly without hints.
That works out to 3 minutes per puzzle, and that's not including the victory gift animation.

This is a collection of easy to medium (at best) puzzles of 14 types. The most interesting one is the code puzzle, but there are only 35 of those in challenge mode. Most of the puzzle types suffer from the small size; they seem designed to be displayed on much smaller devices than computer monitor.

Localization: You have a choice of British and American English, plus 4 other languages. The german localization is patchy, with Wortkette"  converting ÄÖÜ to AOU
date: and occasional spelling errors (most noteable "Paneten" having the planet "Merker"). Also
recommended: the German keyboard layout doesn't work (Y <-> Z).\n\nAlthough it's on sale for -.99
hoursPlayed: I give it a thumbs down since I know a few independent puzzle games that give more bang for your buck
voteText: e.g. the games by Kris Pixton or Everett Kaser (not on Steam). You can play those games for years
helpfulPercent: and their difficulty starts at 3-5 minutes per puzzle instead of ending there."

reviewText:

Biggest suggestion is make sure you pick the correct language.  I first didn't notice there was English AND American.  Made the crosswords a lot harder because of slang I had zero knowledge of.  And the bonus hint tokens don't transfer.

I do really love the hint token and the exchange system.  I really like how you can purchase" specific hints based on needs and they have varying costs.

Also
date: the abilty to skip around on the huge challenge board is fun.  It's a good way to store up hint tokens on puzzles you're better at than others and can provide a break from other puzzle types when you're just not feeling up for them.\n\nNot sure what I'll do when the challenge is full but seeing as how I may be 50 puzzles in

reviewText:
Puzzler World is a case of what you see is what you get, a collection of over 1200 puzzles of 8 different varieties, it's incredibly cheap to buy and simple to play, but is also ridiculously easy, almost as if the game was designed with only children under the age of 8 in mind. One of the 8 puzzle types is quite literally the same thing as a colouring book.

There isn't much else to say here. If you're looking for something challenging, then this game isn't for you, unless you're 8 years old or younger. The Crossword, Codeword and Fitword puzzles can be mildly complex, but that's all.

On a side note, I have absolutely no idea how I came into possession of this game. I just happened to see it in my Steam library and it's certainly not something I would buy while normally browsing Steam.

reviewText: Puzzler World is the first of the best 2 part game series on the planet, Puzzler World really shows how a good game is made. There are so many FANTASTIC puzzles to choose from and the prizes are unbelievable! This game should be a $60 game because of how deep the campaign mode really gets, and how immersive the game is when your playing it. There is absolutely nothing bad to say about Puzzler World and it should be IGN's #1 game of All-Time. There has never been a game that has made me cry when the campaign ended but this did, [SPOILER ALERT] the fact that Jacob Giancola (the main character) overcomes his addiction to link-a-pix and defeats the evil dragon puzzle was just truly astounding. The way the final cutscene looked was better than watching it happen if it was in real life. There will never be a game so memorable than Puzzler World, besides of course Puzzler World 2 which brings back Christo♥♥♥♥ingidiot to life after he dies in the crossword puzzle section of the first game. I reccomend this game to anyone who loves a very interesting story mode, UNREAL graphics, and perfect controls and gameplay. I give Puzzler World 8/8 m8 and I would indeed play this entire game all over again. There will never be any game created that is as good as this masterpiece, not even Call of Duty. I cant finish this review because of how much I am crying remembering the amazing campaign, so I will end it here. Puzzler World is love. Puzzler World is life.

reviewText:
This isn't really a PC game - sure, it runs on PC, but it's not accomplishing anything that the puzzles in the newspaper do, or a puzzle book.  It's not telling a story, or providing you with a journey, like Myst and other such games, it's just providing Sudoku and word puzzles.

Some people may really like such games - you can play them for free over the web, this is something HTML can provide, without spending a cent.   So what's this game doing, asking for money on Steam?   Asking for thumbs down, that's what.

Existential issues aside, the other reasons not to buy this:  The interface isn't really aimed at PC, you can't change the resolution (although it does have a handy handwriting recognition capability, because presumably the developers didn't know about keyboards).   So it runs at about 800x600 whether you like it or not.   As I said - it's not even a PC game.

Fun puzzle games presented very well.  The variety and sequence lets you play a long time and not get bored or you could just spend a few minutes at a time, filling in idle moments.  Note this is free with Puzzler World 2.

Puzzler World is not a difficult game, though everyone of all ages and skill level will have fun playing. Difficulty ranges from extremely easy to medium. But becareful! Some of the challenges look harder than they appear...
Decent puzzle game, I got it from one of the Bundle Star bundle. Most puzzles are decent except many of them are too easy (took less than 15 second to solve).\n\nCan 100% achievment in 3 hours.
good
They're puzzles, what did you think you were getting.  Sudoku, word search, crosswords, pretty basic stuff.  Could stand to get a graphics and sound update, otherwise good, casual diversions

The puzzles are terribly easy, and some can't even be considered puzzles. Not worth the price, but I've seen it 90% off and in bundles, where it becomes a decent choice if you want something to kill a few minutes here and there.

I'd agree with the reviews that say this is a good game for people who enjoy puzzles.  Nothing too fancy and you can turn off the music (thank goodness).  At $.49 this is a no brainer.

Edit: Now that I have played this game for a while I thought I'd add a few thoughts.  The puzzles really are quite simple and the gameplay gets...lackluster...after a while.  I don't think I'd pay more than I did for the game but it does allow for just a quick gaming session when I feel like it.

One thing that really annoys me is that the game starts with the music on.  You have to go through the user selection before the options actually are set.  I always hit the mute button before starting the game just so I don't have to listen to it.

I have spent a lot of time playing this game and really love it.  The puzzles start out easy in Challenge mode, but once you get to around 150 (which you can skip to) they become harder.  For instance the beginning Sudokus only have 6 numbers, but later on they are the standard 9.  Fitword becomes more difficult and other puzzles become larger such as the word searches, jigsaw and chain letters.

The hint system is quite good if you get stuck.  An option in many of the puzzles is to remove all mistakes so you can see where you went wrong and finish them yourself such as in Link-A-Pix.  You can also get more standard hints such as filling in a crossword or codeword box.

You have to use hint tokens which have different costs depending on what sort of hint, but you get so many that you never have to worry about it.  I'm on puzzle 180 or so and have over 3k when filling in a crossword letter takes 5.

None of the puzzles so far have been overwhelming hard for me, but the difficulty may increase yet again as I progress even further.
Pretty fun when you have nothing to do and I mean for $5.00 no, but for $0.49 cents sure go ahead buy it.
Great time waster to grab when it's on sale.
The puzzles aren't always challenging, but it's a good game for people who just want to solve puzzles for a while. It really reminds me of the puzzle books my grandmother used to buy.

reviewText: Worth a look if you like puzzle magazines.  It contains some classics, crosswords, word seeks, Sudoku, and several other game types.  The interface is pretty good (better in many respects than Puzzle World 2's), the puzzle scale harder and harder as you go.  And you get some bonuses, like Hangman, after you've beaten a puzzle.  A good way to kill some time.  Despite being originally made for the DS (hence the handwriting portion), it has been converted well to the PC.
Puzzling and relaxing in the sun.

This game is a simple game with many puzzles to do. Not the best graphics, but it is a puzzle game so who cares. Controls are slightly wonky. Kinda boring at start, but starts to get challenging and more enjoyable later on. Achievements are incredibly easy to get. Link-a-pix is my personal favourite puzzle/game.\n\nOverall 7.5/10

I originally bought this for the Nintendo 3DS, and was immensely excited to find it here! Now, I can have it on the go, and at home with different puzzles and hours of fun gameplay!

At first looks very boring (what could you expect from game you got free) but actually is very interesting game, yeah i couldn't believe it, just simple puzzles, nothing special. You can play few variations of mind games, from sudoku to crosswords. Atmosphere is quite good, doesn't get boring quicly, perfect for those days when you don't have to work.

The puzzles are terribly easy, and some can't even be considered puzzles. Not worth the price, but I've seen it 90% off and in bundles, where it becomes a decent choice if you want something to kill a few minutes here and there.

Puzzler World is a huge collection of your usual puzzles, from your math-logical Sudoku to strict knowledge of Crossword kind of puzzles.

All packed under the interface that seemed to be designed for a smartphone. Or Nintendo DS. I am not sure. But for sure, puzzle wasn't done good for a selection of over 1200 puzzles, it's just many many pages of puzzle selection tiles, fitting in 4x4 square.

It also gives you hints points after solcing a puzzle, which is randomly determinated. All done with a fake choice feeling due to it giving you three present boxes to choose, but it's all random anyway, so yes. Then you can use hints during the puzzle for help, like me not being able to solve a single crossword by myself.

And well, since some people like different puzzles, at least it does one thing good - allows you to choose any puzzle from all selection. Aside from another half of puzzle types puzzles that you only after solving one main puzzle. So, not so nice, actually.

Actually, it's hard to review it, it's just collection of various games. It's OK. It does things, gives you fun of types you want and is a bit clumpsy. Also, no awesome music. Shame.

As for me, I am there only for Link-A-Pix puzzles.

I'd agree with the reviews that say this is a good game for people who enjoy puzzles.  Nothing too fancy and you can turn off the music (thank goodness).  At $.49 this is a no brainer.

Edit: Now that I have played this game for a while I thought I'd add a few thoughts.  The puzzles really are quite simple and the gameplay gets...lackluster...after a while.  I don't think I'd pay more than I did for the game but it does allow for just a quick gaming session when I feel like it.

One thing that really annoys me is that the game starts with the music on.  You have to go through the user selection before the options actually are set.  I always hit the mute button before starting the game just so I don't have to listen to it.

Our math teacher used to give us pages from the print version of Puzzler world to complete for extra credit. In a bit of nostalgia and impulse spending during the steam sale, I picked up Puzzler world in a bundle.\n\nIt's exactly what you'd expect. Crosswords, hangman, sudoku. If you want puzzles to fill your idle time, this is a good collection in a simple format that works.

Terrible user interface, pointless games. If you want to play a crossword or sudoku puzzle, there are thousands of alternatives -- many of which are free, all of which are better. Most of the other, obscure games included are tedious, unrewarding, and I don't know who the target audience would be or why anyone would want to play them.\n\nI wouldn't recommend this game for anyone older than 13, and even for small children, I am positive better alternative exist.

Wasn't really expecting much from the game given that it was so cheap. It's not graphically appealing and there's no story to be had. That said: it's an enormous collection of puzzles that you can pick up to kill some time without feeling too invested.

Overview/Pros:You can have unlimited puzzles[completely random], or you can do challenge mode, which features 1,120 puzzles in all.
-Varying difficulties
-Hints to help
-Variety of puzzles
-Unlimited Puzzles[Goes through randomizer]

My Gaming Channel
My Puzzler World 2010 Walkthrough


Main Puzzles:Wordsearch
Sudoku
Crossword
Spot The Difference
Link-a-Pix
Fitword
Codeword
Silhouette

Secondary Puzzles:Chain Letters - link letters to make a word
Equate - # ? # ? # = #
Hangman - solve the phrase
Jigsaw - slide to make the picture.
Missing Piece - Which one is the right piece?
Picture Quiz - three questions about the picture.

Cons -Would've preferred a better sudoku engine/can't use number once in all boxes/small stuff like that.
-Some puzzle types have more than others.

I would not say my playtime is accurately represented since I have fallen asleep while doing these puzzles...[from being tired]

reviewText: First of all, I'd like to say that I love puzzle games. Saw that Puzzler World" is for sale at 49 cents and it was a must buy
date: lol. That's a very nice deal that I got. Why? - you may ask. Well
recommended: there are 8 puzzle types and over 1100 different puzzles in Challenge Mode. If you got stuck at solving a puzzle you can use hint tokens. You earn them by completing puzzles. I used a lot of those for crosswords as I am not very good at them. Really fun game and if you can get it at this price it's a steal. For real. Got 100% achievements in 8 hours but might play more. I usually don't play games that I already "completed" (earned 100% achievements) but I can do an exception for this one. :P Also
hoursPlayed: I noticed that there is a sequel and it's also worth 49 cents. Damn
voteText: I feel so lucky. :D I used to solve such puzzles in a notebook when I am not on the PC but now I can do that in these games. And let's be serious - you can't even buy a newspaper with a crossword for this price. So
helpfulPercent: my point is that if you like puzzles you'd love "Puzzler World". Grab 'em while they're hot
